headline.main: Analysis of Obama's State of the Union Address

docs.abstract: The president highlighted progress on the economy, U.S.-Cuba relations and gas prices, and he called for a renewed focus on economic inequality.
docs.snippet: The president highlighted progress on the economy, U.S.-Cuba relations and gas prices, and he called for a renewed focus on economic inequality.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the past 50 years, meat has gotten less fatty and easier to chew — thanks in part to the U.S. Meat Animal Research Center. But the achievement has come at a steep cost to the lab’s animals.

headline.seo: Animal Welfare at Risk in Experiments for Meat Industry
headline.main: U.S. Research Lab Lets Livestock Suffer in Quest for Profit
headline.print_headline: In Quest for More Meat Profits, U.S. Lab Lets Animals Suffer

docs.abstract: US Meat Animal Research Center in Nebraska has re-engineered farm animals with several distinct market advantages, but changes have come at cruel cost for the animals; taxpayer-funded research has yielded less costly animals with more offspring and leaner and more plentiful meat, but many of them are born weakened and deformed, dying in huge numbers or living brief lives of intense suffering.
docs.snippet: In the past 50 years, meat has gotten less fatty and easier to chew — thanks in part to the U.S. Meat Animal Research Center. But the achievement has come at a steep cost to the lab’s animals.

docs.lead_paragraph: KAUFFMAN--Joel M.,PhD. 78, retired chemistry professor from the University of the Sciences in Philadelphia, researcher, consultant, and medical writer died at Paoli Hospital on January 5, 2015 of natural causes. Born in Philadelphia on January 3, 1937, son of the late David and Mathilde (Goldstein) Kauffman and predeceased by his sister Melanie, he leaves his wife of eight years Frances Heckert Pane, her daughter Natalia Pane Tyrka and grandchildren, his sister Ellen Navin, nephews Jason Levy, David O'Connor, and niece Corrine O'Connor. He received a B.S. in Chemistry from the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and Science (now USP) and a PhD in Organic Chemistry from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He worked in the Boston area for 11 years in the chemical industry including four years at the Massachusetts College of Pharmacy and Health Sciences. In 1979 he returned to the University of the Sciences in Philadelphia where he rose to professor, retiring after 23 years. Author of 80 papers covering chemical and medical research, he has 11 patents on potential immunogenetic anticancer drugs, antituberculosis drugs, design of radiation-hard fluors, development of oligophenylene laser dyes, and photophysical properties of proton-transfer fluors. In retirement, supported by his extensive study of existing research, he wrote "Malignant Medical Myths," an expose of the revered dogma preached by mainstream medicine. In his continuous search for the truth, Joel was skeptical of everything until proven to be correct. In retirement, he was a founding member of THINCS.org International Network of Cholesterol Skeptics. 1/3

docs.lead_paragraph:
KAUFFMAN--Joel M., PhD.

78, retired chemistry professor from the University of the Sciences in Philadelphia, researcher, consultant, and medical writer died at Paoli Hospital on January 5, 2015 of natural causes. Born in Philadelphia on January 3, 1937, son of the late David and Mathilde (Goldstein) Kauffman and predeceased by his sister Melanie, he leaves his wife of eight years Frances Heckert Pane, her daughter Natalia Pane Tyrka and grandchildren, his sister Ellen Navin, nephews Jason Levy, David O'Connor, and niece Corrine O'Connor. He received a B.S. in Chemistry from the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and Science (now USP) and a PhD in Organic Chemistry from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He worked in the Boston area for 11 years in the chemical industry including four years at the Massachusetts College of Pharmacy and Health Sciences. In 1979 he returned to the University of the Sciences in Philadelphia where he rose to professor, retiring after 23 years. Author of 80 papers covering chemical and medical research, he has 11 patents on potential immunogenetic anticancer drugs, antituberculosis drugs, design of radiation-hard fluors, development of oligophenylene laser dyes, and photophysical properties of proton-transfer fluors. In retirement, supported by his extensive study of existing research, he wrote "Malignant Medical Myths," an expose of the revered dogma preached by mainstream medicine. In his continuous search for the truth, Joel was skeptical of everything until proven to be correct. In retirement, he was a founding member of THINCS.org International Network of Cholesterol Skeptics.

docs.lead_paragraph: The health care giant, collaborating with Yale, made the announcement on the same day that the Institute of Medicine urged sponsors of clinical trials to share data.

headline.main: Johnson & Johnson Will Make Clinical Data Available to Outside Researchers
headline.print_headline: Johnson & Johnson Will Make Clinical Data Available to Outside Researchers

docs.abstract: Johnson & Johnson announces collaboration with Yale University to give outside researchers access to detailed clinical trial data about its medical devices; National Academy of Sciences' Institute of Medicine separately urges sharing of study data with outside researchers by all sponsors of clinical trials soon after a product is approved; industry has resisted sharing data, concerned about trade secrets and patient privacy.
docs.snippet: The health care giant, collaborating with Yale, made the announcement on the same day that the Institute of Medicine urged sponsors of clinical trials to share data.
